text: this is Damian cave reporting for the
New York Times from Mexico City traffic
I'm trying to get through an
intersection that's pretty much the bane
of my existence
on a bad day it takes me nearly a half
hour just to go a few hundred feet a big
part of the problem of course is that
too many people here insist on driving
but this intersection also features a
subway station and there are just way
too many taxis that stuff to pick people
up the traffic police tend to just stand
around even when there are people
running red lights like this guy what's
interesting is what happens because
we're all stuck in place a bad
intersection like this one creates a
captive audience and a whole lot of
people who were trying to turn drivers
into customers when I came to this
intersection this morning this is who I
found
there were also a bunch of guys who said
they were waiting to be sent somewhere
for a day of manual labor other
intersections like this one a few blocks
away have their own forms of a creative
salesmanship this mine is one of my
personal favorites but no matter where
you are it's hard not to marvel at just
how much there is to see in this city
while trapped behind the wheel drivers
do all kinds of things to pass the time
and yes in case you were wondering
talking on the cell phone is illegal
here not that anyone pays attention to
the law personally I always appreciate
the people selling food or just those
brave enough to push it through the
streets this is another guy I see a lot
I think he's selling a bug zephyr but
I'm not really sure altogether the more
time I've spent here the more I've come
to see this intersection as a microcosm
of Mexico itself this is a country where
six out of every ten workers toils in
the informal economy and yet it's also
increasingly middle-class which means
more drivers and more traffic that's why
whenever I can I decide to walk
you
